block.p: ''P.S. I Loved You,'' by Aimee Mann (Op-Ed, June 3), shares an interesting perspective on why she cannot bear listening to ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' as an adult musician: She fears it's not the achievement it seemed when she was a youth, surpassed by the better melodies and lyrics of others.

''P.S. I Loved You,'' by Aimee Mann (Op-Ed, June 3), shares an interesting perspective on why she cannot bear listening to ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' as an adult musician: She fears it's not the achievement it seemed when she was a youth, surpassed by the better melodies and lyrics of others.

All in all, she says, it is ''like realizing you can beat your own father at chess or arm-wrestling.'' And that's a downer. But in this case, Dad is a bit more than a chess dilettante; he's the one who tore up the rulebook and rewrote it for generations to come.

Sure, others have been able to take popular music to new heights or have achieved greater depth -- maybe Ms. Mann among them. But they are building on a foundation that the Beatles, more than anyone else, helped establish.
Perhaps Ms. Mann will write her next Op-Ed essay after she's recorded something as utterly revolutionary or influential as ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band,'' ''Revolver'' or ''Abbey Road.''
Steven Brett Buffalo Grove, Ill., June 3, 2007
